It will soon be legal for residents of New Jersey to gamble online.
Yesterday, the state's governor, Chris Christie, signed a bill that allows people to play games like blackjack and poker over the Internet.
New Jersey is one of the first states to make such a move.
As we hear from NPR's Jim Zarroli, several states are rushing to establish a foothold in online gambling.
It's an activity federal officials were only recently trying to ban.
Governor Christie had expressed reservations about online gambling just a month ago and had vetoed an earlier version of the bill.
But in the end, the pressure to sign the legislation was just too great.
Father Richard McGowan of Boston College, who studies legalized gambling, says the state's struggling casino industry sees the Internet as a rich source of new revenue.
Their newest casino just went bankrupt.
Two of their other casinos got sold for less than $20 million.
Atlantic City is in real trouble.
So, Christie is trying to do anything right now to try to save Atlantic City.
And McGowan says New Jersey is eager to reap tax revenues from online gambling, and it's competing with other states to break into the industry first.
Nevada, in particular, has already taken steps to legalize the activity and so has Delaware.
But there are plenty of potential pitfalls.
Until recently, the federal government actually viewed online gambling as a crime.
More recently, the Obama administration has taken a more permissive stance.
It now allows states to sell lottery tickets online, for instance.
But McGowan says the legalities of Internet gambling are still being worked out.
I'm just wondering who is going to be running it.
How are they going to be regulated?
How much are the states going to be willing to spend to regulate this stuff?
It's going to be a good question.
There are also big technical questions about online gambling.
The New Jersey bill limits the activity to people who are actually physically present in the state.
So, New Jersey companies that set up gambling websites will have to find ways to keep people in other states from accessing them.
Casino industry officials say technology exists to do that.
The bill also will require companies to spend money on gambling treatment programs.
Donald Weinbaum, of the Council of Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, says with Internet access, people will no longer have to go to a casino to wager money.
